conclusion: Place a horizontal axis along the floor with the point light source as the origin, x = 0, the right-hand vertical wall at x = 2a, and the ball projected straight up from the midpoint, x = a.
At any instant t, the ball’s height above the floor is y(t) = v₀ t − ½ g t².
Draw the ray of light that goes from the source (0,0) through the ball (a, y) and meets the wall at x = 2a.
Using similar triangles, the height of the shadow on the wall is Y(t) = 2 y(t) = 2v₀ t − g t².
The instantaneous (vertical) velocity of the shadow is the time derivative of Y(t): V_shadow(t) = dY/dt = 2v₀ − 2g t.
The initial velocity of the shadow (t = 0) is V_shadow(0) = 2v₀.
The shadow starts upward with an initial velocity equal to twice the ball’s initial velocity, i.e., V_shadow, 0 = 2 v₀.
